A safai (cleanliness) day was held with the /\ participation of the municipal corporation's administrator to raise awareness. Program Implementation Once households had been sufficiently motivated, the members were given two garbage X bags, dark blue for organic waste, and white for non-organic waste. Most of the waste t 995 - collected was organic as the inorganic junk was kept for its resale value by the household 1> 1997 members themselves. The bags were collected twice weekly by waste collectors and sent to Z1 t the compost farm in the village of Regi. Waste was further sorted there by the waste collectors to separate saleable junk (bottles, plastic, paper, tin, etc.) and ensure that only non-organic waste was sold or disposed of in municipal dumps. A hujra committee of household members was formed which collected the service charge of Rs 15 per month. All accounts of receipts and expenditures were kept by the committee. The organic waste is stored in pits and left covered for 4-6 weeks until composting is complete. The first yield of compost was given free of cost to the landlord of the compost farm. Subsequently compost was packed in 1 kg bags and sold forRs 15 ($ 0.4) per kg. The income from the sale, which in 1997 amounted toRs 3,400 ($ 85), was ploughed back into the program. Follow up & Support Prior to handing over to the CBO, a Female Social Organizer (FSO) used to visit the area three times a week on alternate days. The first day was spent on providing primary health an 1995.- hygiene education to female members either individually or during group meetings. The > 1998 second day was spent in explaining how to separate the waste into organic and non-organic components. Initial mistakes were corrected with the guidance of the FSO. The third day was spent in supporting and monitoring the work of the community teacher. Male, and from September 1997, female social organizers held weekly meetings with the community to discuss progress, motivation and to facilitate the resolution of any problems. Now that the project is in the hands of the community, it is the community members who hold these meetings where project monitoring is also discussed. All minutes of the meetings and 4 proposed actions are recorded.
